metadata.title: Popliteal Cysts in Adults
description: The term popliteal cyst (also called Baker’s cyst) indicates the benign enlargement of a bursa in the posterior knee due to collection of synovial fluid from the knee capsule. It usually is characterized by minor swelling of the popliteal fossa, which in most cases is asymptomatic. Severe swelling may, however, cause discomfort due to compression of a nerve or blood vessel(1,14)

The involved bursa typically is found in the medial aspect of the popliteal fossa between the semimembranosus tendon and the medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle, just below crease of knee. This gastrocnemius-semimembranosus  bursa is unique because it communicates with the knee joint via an opening (one-way  valve effect) in the joint capsule posterior to the medial femoral condyle(4,13)
The majority of adult popliteal cysts are associated with primary osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee, meniscus tears, anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) insufficiency, and/or chondral lesions(14)

ICD-10 codes.M71.20: synovial cyst of popliteal space [Baker], unspecified knee
ICD-10 codes.M71.21: synovial cyst of popliteal space (Baker), right knee
ICD-10 codes.M66.0: rupture of popliteal cyst (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: A bulge/popliteal swelling may be palpable and/or visible in the posterior knee
The patient may complain of tenderness, limited end ROM, swelling, stiffness, or pain with activity (e.g., squatting)(1)

Coexisting knee joint pathology (e.g., cruciate ligament tears, meniscal tears, degenerative joint disease) often contributes to the presentation of swelling, instability, and impaired movement(14) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: The assessment should include evaluation for coexisting knee joint pathology
Pulsatile popliteal mass can suggest pseudoaneurysm(5)

Stop examination immediately and notify physician if signs of DVT, infection, malignancy, compartment syndrome, or neuropathies are present. Compression neuropathy of the common peroneal nerve has been reported(8)
If characteristics of the mass are unusual on physical exam, refer back to physician for MRI/ultrasonography(5)

causes: Popliteal cysts are classified as either primary (i.e., isolated swelling) or secondary (i.e.,excess synovial fluid entering the bursa from the knee joint)(1,14)

The majority of popliteal cysts are secondary to some internal knee joint derangement,where the bursa has a communicating path of synovial fluid from the knee joint. Chronicknee effusion leads to enlargement of the bursa. Meniscal tears (70% medial), followedby ACL and/or chondral lesions, have been described as the main cause(13,14)

Primary popliteal cysts have no communication with the knee joint and usually are caused by direct trauma or someisolated inflammatory condition.(1) Because primary cysts in children commonly are asymptomatic, their discovery is oftenby chance.(For more information, see Clinical Review…Popliteal Cysts in Pediatric Patients ; Topic ID Number: T708524)
pathogenesis: A popliteal cyst is a fluid-filled  mass that arises from the distension of a pre-existing  bursa, which is commonly thegastrocnemio-semimembranosus bursa(4,14)

It is thought that most popliteal cysts develop when synovial fluid passes through a unidirectional valvular mechanismof the capsular fold in the posteromedial capsule and collects in the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus  bursa.(4,14)This“communicating bursa” is more prevalent in older adults with popliteal cysts
Distension of the bursa gives the clinical and radiographic appearance of a cyst

Knee joint pathology or trauma usually accounts for the increased synovial effusion. Injuries to the medial meniscus andarticular cartilage show the highest correlation with popliteal cysts.(13)A popliteal cyst without intra-articular  abnormalitiesoften is painless
risk factors: Intra-articular  knee joint pathology that causes inflammation and knee joint effusion (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis,osteoarthritis, cartilage degeneration, medial plicae, torn meniscus, cruciate ligament tears). Popliteal cyst volumecorrelates with the intra-articular  effusion(11)
Age, sex, and BMI are not associated with risk for popliteal cysts(3)

overall contraindications precautions: Popliteal cysts in adults can rupture and extravasate into the proximal calf, producing pseudothrombophlebitis; i.e., symptoms that mimic DVT(1) (see Clinical Review…Deep Vein Thrombosis: Exercise ; Topic ID Number: T708457). Thus, differentiating between a ruptured popliteal cyst and a DVT is crucial.(1,12)Both may exhibit a positive Foucher’s sign (see Special tests , below).(14)A Doppler ultrasound test will differentiate between the two suspected diagnoses. If a DVT is mistakenly diagnosed and the patient is put on a therapeutic dose of low-molecular-weight  heparin, major bleeding may complicate the Baker’s cyst and may cause compartment syndrome(12)
Other complications known to occur after a cyst rupture are compartment syndromes and neuropathies(1)
Malignancy should be considered if the symptoms change abruptly or if fever or night pain accompanies the cyst(1,9)
Common peroneal nerve compression caused by an extraneural popliteal cyst is rare but has been found in symptomatic patients(8)
Differential diagnosis should include popliteal artery and vein aneurysm, as these conditions can present as a popliteal mass(5,9)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: The assessment should include evaluation for coexisting knee joint pathology
Pulsatile popliteal mass can suggest pseudoaneurysm(5)

Stop examination immediately and notify physician if signs of DVT, infection, malignancy, compartment syndrome, or neuropathies are present. Compression neuropathy of the common peroneal nerve has been reported(8)
If characteristics of the mass are unusual on physical exam, refer back to physician for MRI/ultrasonography(5)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Patients describe either a gradual or a sudden onset of fullness/swelling in the posterior knee. When did symptoms of popliteal cyst begin? Was prior co-existing  knee joint pathology present? See Causes , above, for more details

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about any past or current interventions for this condition. What is the patient’s current WB status?
surgical management: Surgical management: Surgery may be required to remove symptomatic popliteal cysts that do not respond to conservative management.(1,4,7) Ask if there was a concurrent meniscal tear and debridement or any postoperative complications after knee surgery
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the clinician has prescribed; are they being taken and are they effective? NSAIDs may be prescribed to decrease pain and inflammation
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Imaging with ultrasonography, arthrography with contrast dye, or MRI (considered the gold standard) may be employed to either confirm the presence of a popliteal cyst or to exclude other causes of symptoms. Standard radiographs may detect calcified loose bodies in the popliteal space(1,14)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Vague discomfort develops into a dull ache made worse by aggravating activities such as running, kneeling, squatting, or walking. End-of-range  knee movements will also cause discomfort(1,4)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Patients usually complain of posterior knee pain
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). In classic cases, there is dull or aching posterior knee pain
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Increased pain at night may indicate a malignancy
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any previous problems, surgery, or injury to the involved knee? Intraarticular  pathology may help explain the joint effusion. Check for cardiac history/issues to rule out any vascular problems
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask whether treated for other ongoing medical conditions, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient work? What job duties are performed?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Complete a general assessment as indicated with a focus on the items listed below
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight. Document BMI. Is weight loss indicated to reduce disability on WB?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess for appropriate use and fit of assistive device (e.g., crutches) if appropriate
relevant tests and measures.balance: An uncomplicated popliteal cyst should not impair balance
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Pedal pulses may be slightly diminished if popliteal swelling is severe. Tenderness over distal veins orExercise , referenced above)Measure knee circumference for swelling, as indicated. Measure calf circumference if swelling is noted there. Compare to uninvolved limb
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: An antalgic gait pattern is more likely caused by knee joint pathology than a popliteal cyst. However, the patient may not fully extend the knee during gait because more tension is placed on a popliteal cyst in full knee extension (which may lead to increased pain)(14)Because it is extracapsular, a popliteal cyst should not affect knee joint mechanics unless swelling is significant(1)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of lower extremity using manual muscle testing (MMT). The hamstrings and gastrocnemius and soleus muscles should be closely evaluated, as contraction of these muscles when the knee is extended is known to increase tension on popliteal cysts and, therefore, increase symptoms(14)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Motion at the knee may be restricted depending on the size of the popliteal cyst.(1) Assess knee ROM, paying attention to end-of-range  flexion and/or extension restriction and/or complaints of painAssess ability to kneel and squat and other ADLs as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: If the dermatome scan is abnormal, further neurological testing should be performed (e.g., reflex testing)(1)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisWith the patient lying prone, the posterior knee/cyst is palpated during knee extension and flexion. This maneuver may assist in differentiating a popliteal cyst from other posterior knee masses, as a popliteal cyst softens or disappears in knee flexion to 45°, whereas other masses may stay firm.(14)Foucher’s sign is seen on resisted flexion with the knee in full extension. The popliteal cyst becomes harder, the semimembranosus is more prominent, and the cleft between the cyst and the semimembranosus becomes deeperAbruptly dorsiflex the ankle while the knee is slightly flexed. Pain in the popliteal space or calf would constitute a positive sign. The test will also be positive if a DVT is present (this is the reason a ruptured popliteal cyst is also known as a pseudothrombophlebitis). Unfortunately, the physical findings of the two conditions are indistinguishable (calf pain and swelling), thus requiring the patient to be referred to a physician, who will most likely order a DopplerExercise , referenced above)To check for the presence of a meniscal injury, which is the most common cause of secondary popliteal T708409)To check for the presence of a cruciate ligament injury in the knee, which is a common cause of secondary popliteal cysts.(4)(For more information, see Clinical Review…Anterior CruciateT708741 and/or see Clinical Review…Posterior Cruciate Ligament InjuryT708630)  –Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) –International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) score

cryotherapy contraindications: Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
cryotherapy precautions: Uncontrolled hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment
Promote adherence to WB orders from physician and, if necessary, provide appropriate assistive device for maintenance of these orders
Any serious medical condition or underlying joint pathology (e.g., DVT, cruciate ligament injury, meniscus injury) should be identified prior to initiating treatment(1)
Evidence is lacking to support the use of electrotherapeutic modalities for treating popliteal cysts

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Symptomatic popliteal cyst/therapeutic intervention to address functional deficits related to extrinsic and intrinsic factors associated with patient’s symptoms; conservative regimen to reduce pain, restore function, and resolve effusion
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out  (9) Popliteal aneurysm Tumor(1) Subgastrocnemius bursitis(3) Synovial hemangioma(14) DVT Rupture of cyst Hamstring, gastrocnemius, or popliteus tendon injury Sepsis(1) Lipoma(5)
prognosis: The prognosis depends on the underlying knee joint pathology(1)
An uncomplicated popliteal cyst seldom causes long-term  disability
Current opinion is that symptoms related only to the popliteal cyst will likely resolve with treatment of coexisting knee joint pathology(14)
Outcomes of physical rehabilitation depend largely on the knee condition(s) associated with the popliteal cyst(4)

Arthroscopic excision of popliteal cysts exhibited improved clinical outcomes compared to a traditional open surgical approach(10) –Based on a study in China in which 76 patients with popliteal cysts were randomized into 3 groups: arthroscopic internal drainage, arthroscopic drainage then open excision, and open excision –Recurrence rate was significantly lower in the arthroscopic drainage group –The incision healing time, hospitalization length of stay, and Lysholm score at follow-up  were higher in the open excision groups
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Diagnostic imaging (ultrasound, MRI) may be necessary to assist in ruling out other knee conditions. An uncomplicated popliteal cyst should not be treated surgically. However, referral for surgery will be likely if conservative care fails(1)
treatment summary: Asymptomatic cysts typically are treated conservatively(1)

Guidelines are lacking for rehabilitative care of popliteal cysts. Low-quality evidence is based on a few cases of complicated cysts treated surgically. The primary components of a conservative treatment plan are relative rest, activity modification, pain management, therapeutic exercises to regain knee strength and ROM, patient education, and NSAIDs

Authors of a case series (N = 29 patients, ages 43–77  years) found that arthroscopic decompression was effective treatment for symptomatic popliteal cysts. Twelve cysts resolved completely, 16 were reduced in size, and one enlarged(6)

Authors of a meta-analysis  of 11 studies of the clinical efficacy of different surgical procedures concluded that arthroscopic management of the intra-articular lesion and enlarging the communication valve between cyst and posteromedial capsule (96.7% success rate) or excision of the cyst wall (98.2% success rate) are ideal management strategies(13)

Similar to knee surgery for other reasons, postoperative care involves 4 days of non-WB  followed by partial WB for 10 days. Full WB usually is initiated 2 weeks after surgery. Flexibility and strengthening (open-  and closed-  chain) exercises for the knee and lower extremity are then initiated with the expectation of returning to full activity by 8 weeks(1) .
